```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)
library(fs)
library(tidymodels)
library(tidyverse)

```



```{r download, cache=TRUE}
download.file(url = "https://github.com/TheUpshot/2018-live-poll-results/archive/master.zip",
              destfile = "master.zip",
              quiet = TRUE,
              mode = "wb")

unzip("master.zip")

raw <- fs::dir_ls("2018-live-poll-results-master/data") %>%
  map_dfr(read_csv, 
          .id = "source", 
          col_types = cols(
                           .default = col_character(),
                           turnout_scale = col_double(),
                           turnout_score = col_double(),
                           w_LV = col_double(),
                           w_RV = col_double(),
                           final_weight = col_double(),
                           timestamp = col_datetime(format = "")
                            ))


file_delete(c("master.zip", "2018-live-poll-results-master"))

```

```{r clean}
# Data is somewhat messy. Some of our functions require that the variable be a
# factor with two levels, rather than a simple 0/1 variable. Many of the
# variables in the original data are missing for thousands of observations.
# Maybe clean up this code to do all the as.factor at the end?

x <- raw %>% 
  mutate(dvote = as.factor(ifelse(response == "Dem", "Yes", "No"))) %>% 
  mutate(gender = as.factor(ifelse(gender == "Female", "Female", "Male"))) %>% 
  
  mutate(party = factor(case_when(
    partyid %in% c("Democrat", "Republican") ~ partyid,
    partyid == "Independent (No party)" ~ "Independent",
    TRUE ~ "Other"), levels = c("Democrat", "Republican", "Independent", "Other"))) %>% 
  
  # Might add some other variables later. Maybe only dvote really needs to be a
  # factor?
  
  select(dvote, gender, party)


```

```{r make_a_model}

model_1 <- glm(data = x, dvote ~ gender, family = "binomial")

x <- x %>% 
  mutate(prediction = predict(model_1, type = "response")) 

```

```{r add_prediction_back}

x %>% 
  mutate(guess = as.factor(ifelse(prediction > 0.5, "Yes", "No")))

```
